Abandonment and Sealing Notification. For wells designed to be used at a rate of more than 10,000 gallons per day, a licensed well driller shall:
Provide written notification to the Approving Authority that identifies the well to be sealed and an outline of the work to be done;
Identify whether the well casing is to be perforated or ripped; and
Provide 24-hour notification to the Approving Authority before the commencement of sealing operations.
Abandonment and Sealing Approval.
When the Approving Authority has reason to believe that the sealing of a well necessitates close supervision, it may require:
The submission of sealing plans and specifications for approval before sealing operations are initiated; and
24 hours’ notice before the commencement of sealing operations.
The Approving Authority may approve of a well sealing procedure not identified in Regulation .36 of this chapter, provided the sealing procedure complies with Regulation .36D of this chapter.
Reports on the Abandonment and Sealing of Wells.
When a well is abandoned and sealed, the person sealing it shall submit a completed Water Well Abandonment Sealing Report on the form provided by the Approving Authority.
This report shall be submitted not later than 45 days after abandonment and sealing of the well or test hole.
The following sealing materials are acceptable to seal a well:
Concrete when mixed at five 94-pound sacks of Portland cement per yard of concrete;
Neat Portland cement grout when mixed in accordance with Regulation .19 of this chapter;
A mixture of five 94-pound sacks of Portland cement and 1 cubic yard sand;
Bentonite, if used:
As a slurry mixed at 2 pounds per gallon of water; or
In chip or pellet form; and
Combinations of these materials.
Drilling fluid may not to be used to seal a well.
Fill Materials.
Clay, silt, sand, gravel, crushed stone, mixtures of these materials, and sealing materials may be used as a filler in sealing a well.
In the sealing of an unsuccessful well in Hydrogeologic Areas 3, 4, and 5, the drill cuttings may be used as fill material.
Material containing organic matter may not be used.
The Approving Authority may require that fill material be disinfected.
Preliminary Work Before Sealing a Well.
The well shall be investigated to determine:
Its present condition;
The details of its construction; and
Whether there are any obstructions that will interfere with the process of filling and sealing.
If there are any obstructions, they shall be removed, if possible, by cleaning the hole or redrilling.
Liners shall be removed prior to sealing or an alternate sealing plan must be approved by the Approving Authority.
Filling and Sealing Wells.
In all hydrogeologic areas of the State, the annular space of cased wells shall be sealed.
Wells in an unconfined aquifer in Hydrogeologic Areas 1 and 2 shall be sealed by either of the following procedures:
If the well casing is not removed, fill the well with sealing material; or
If the well casing is removed, fill the entire length of the borehole with sealing material.
Wells in a confined aquifer in Hydrogeologic Area 2 shall be filled and sealed by either of the following procedures:
If the casing has been removed, the well shall be filled the entire depth with sealing material; or
If the casing has not been removed:
Consideration shall be given to perforating or ripping the casing opposite the confining layers; and
The well shall be filled with sealing material.
Unconfined wells less than 2-inch diameter shall be sealed only with neat Portland cement.
Wells in Hydrogeologic Areas 3, 4, and 5 Filling and Sealing Procedures.
Fill material shall extend from the bottom of the well to within 20 feet of the casing bottom, except for filling materials used in unsuccessful wells under Regulation .35C(2) of this chapter.
If rapid loss of sealing material into the rock occurs during emplacement, coarse fill material may be used to fill voids.
Placement of Material. The following standards shall be met in placing filling or sealing materials:
The well shall be sealed with the appropriate material emplaced from the top of the fill material;

When neat Portland cement, concrete, or bentonite slurry is used, it shall be placed in one continuous operation utilizing a pipe extended to the bottom of the interval to be sealed except as noted in §D of this regulation;
Bentonite chips or pellets:
Shall be used in such a way as to prevent bridging, but if bridging occurs, the well shall be drilled out;
May not be used for casing diameters smaller than 2 inches; and
Shall follow the specific product manufacturer’s instructions for their use.
Special Procedures for Filling and Sealing Certain Wells.
A dug well shall be filled and sealed by the following procedure:
Placing fill material in the well to a level approximately 5 feet below the land surface;
Placing a 2-feet thick layer of concrete above the fill; and
Filling the remainder of the well to the ground surface.
A monitoring well shall be sealed by the following procedure:
For monitoring wells less than 50 feet in depth:
Ripping or removing the casing; and
Filling the well with sealing material; or
For monitoring wells greater than 50 feet in depth follow the procedures specified in §B of this regulation.
A geothermal well shall be sealed by;
Removing all fluids from the tubing; and
Filling the tubing and any open portion of the borehole with grout.

section.heading: Variances.
section.text: Upon the recommendation of the Approving Authority and the approval of the Department, variances to the distance requirements of the regulations of this chapter for all wells and the construction standards for replacement wells may be granted, provided that the public health and the environment are protected.

para.text: If the Approving Authority determines that there has been a violation of this chapter or of any permit or permit special condition, the Approving Authority shall:
Serve upon the alleged violator a written complaint specifying the nature and extent of the violation, items to be corrected, and time limits for correction; and
Notify the well owner of the violation.
If a person violating a requirement of this chapter cannot correct the violation, the Approving Authority may require abandonment and sealing of the well.

A person aggrieved by a final decision of the Approving Authority in a contested case has the right to have the decision reviewed in accordance with the provisions of the Administrative Procedure Act and other applicable statutes and regulations. All appeals shall be filed with the Director, Water Management Administration, within 30 days after notification of the final decision by the Approving Authority.
A person who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction is subject to the provisions under Environment Article, §9-1311, Annotated Code of Maryland.

A person who knowingly makes any false statement, representation, or certification in any application, record, report, plan, or other document filed or required to be maintained under this chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction is subject to the provisions under Environment Article, §9-1311, Annotated Code of Maryland.
